thread.title: METALS-London zinc jumps after Glencore cuts production
thread.title_full: METALS-London zinc jumps after Glencore cuts production | Reuters

author: Reuters
title: METALS-London zinc jumps after Glencore cuts production
text:
* Glencore to cut 500,000 T of annual zinc capacity
* Coming UP: U.S. Import, Export prices Sep at 1230 GMT (Adds comment, detail, updates prices)
By Melanie Burton
MELBOURNE, Oct 9 (Reuters) - London zinc surged four percent on Friday after top miner Glencore said it would slash its annual output by a third, fanning sentiment that was already brightened by minutes showing the Federal Reserve was in no hurry to raise rates.
Commodities giant Glencore said on Friday it will cut 500,000 tonnes of zinc production, or around 4 percent of global supply, in its latest move to withstand weak commodities prices.
"They have certainly come out on the front foot in shuttering capacity which is obviously a good first step," said analyst Daniel Hynes of ANZ in Sydney.
"We need to see these type of cuts by the wider market before the market will get confident that the metals market balance will tighten."
Three month zinc on the London Metal Exchange jumped 4.1 percent to $1,736 a tonne by 0215 GMT. Technical issues had delayed LME price feeds earlier in the session.
Shanghai zinc gained 2.3 percent to 14,140 yuan ($2,227) a tonne.
Traders noted mine supply had already been set to shrink given the closure of MMG's huge Century mine in Australia and Lisheen in Ireland this year.
"Zinc should outperform the other metals now," said one trader in Singapore.
LME metals rallied in zinc's tailwind. LME lead, which is often mined alongside zinc, jumped 1.7 percent. LME copper climbed 1.2 percent to $5,183 a tonne, while nickel and aluminium also rose between half a percent and one percent.
Metals were also buttressed after minutes of the Federal Reserve's latest meeting led investors to further pare bets that the central bank will hike interest rates this year.
The U.S. Federal Reserve thought the economy was close to warranting an interest rate hike in September but policymakers wanted firmer evidence a global economic slowdown was not knocking America off course. nL1N128230
